Medical Definition of STRATUM BASALE. 1. : the basal layer of the epidermis consisting of a single row of columnar or cuboidal epithelial cells that continually divide and replace the rest of the epidermis as it wears away—called also stratum germinativum; see malpighian layer. 2

Stratum basale. The stratum basale is the deepest layer of the five layers of the epidermis, which is the outer covering of skin in mammals. The stratum basale is a continuous layer of cells. It is often described as one cell thick, though it may in fact be two to three cells thick in glabrous skin and hyperproliferative epidermis.

Stratum basale Definition. It refers to the basal or the deepest of the five layers of the epidermis. It is also known by the names “germative layer” or “basal layer.” Sometimes, it is also referred to as stratum germinativum.

Stratum basale epidermidis. Definition. noun. Latin term for basal cell layer of epidermis, the innermost layer composed of basal cells that lies at the base of the epidermis or above the dermis. Supplement. The cells of this layer are actively dividing to provide new cells to replenish lost skin from normal shedding.

The stratum basale (basal layer, sometimes referred to as stratum germinativum) is the deepest layer of the five epidermis layers, which is the outer covering of skin in mammals. The stratum basale is primarily made up of basal keratinocyte stem cells, which can be considered the stem cells of the epidermis. They divide to form the keratinocytes of the stratum spinosum, which migrate superficially.
